session.name: Contributed Orals: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Op.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.sub_class: T33 Online Modeling and Software Tools
paper.title: Operational Results of LHC Collimator Alignment Using Machine Learning
paper.abstract: A complex collimation system is installed in the Large Hadron Collider to protect sensitive equipment from unavoidable beam losses. The collimators are positioned close to the beam in the form of a hierarchy, which is guaranteed by precisely aligning each collimator with a precision of a few tens of micrometers. During past years, collimator alignments were performed semi-automatically*, such that collimation experts had to be present to oversee and control the alignment. In 2018, machine learning was introduced to develop a new fully-automatic alignment tool, which was used for collimator alignments throughout the year. This paper discusses how machine learning was used to automate the alignment, whilst focusing on the operational results obtained when testing the new software in the LHC. Automatically aligning the collimators decreased the alignment time at injection by a factor of three whilst maintaining the accuracy of the results.
paper.footnote: *G.Valentino et al., "Semi-automatic beam-based LHC collimator alignment", PRSTAB, no.5, 2012.

abstract_log.comments: Thank you for submission of your paper to IPAC'19! I have made some changes to your paper and reprocessed it from source so it is a yellow dot -- please verify them and accept or reject the changes in the IPAC'19 SPMS: (*) Reference spacing was odd; fixed by quoting reference titles with regular LaTeX quotes (*) Figures were too wide at 3.3cm -- used \columnwidth for figure widths to extend to full width of column. Thank you again! -Todd Satogata / satogata@jlab.org
Dear Author, The pdf of your talk is suitable for publication and will be in included in the proceedings (with back-up slides removed). King Regards, jan.chrin@psi.ch

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.sub_class: T33 Online Modeling and Software Tools
paper.title: Status of Automated Optimization Procedures at the European XFEL Accelerator
paper.abstract: The European XFEL is in the operational stage since fall 2017. Since then, tuning of the FEL performance (e.g. of the photon pulse energy) has become increasingly important. Due to a large number of parameters to which FEL facilities are highly sensitive and their complex correlations, controlling and optimizing them in a speedy manner is becoming a very important and challenging task. Several automated optimization procedures were developed to optimize the FEL beam quality. In this work, we present the status and the results of these activities, as well as the optimization statistics.

paper.main_class: MC6: Beam Instrumentation, Controls, Feedback and Operational Aspects
paper.title: The EPICS Software Framework Moves from Controls to Physics
paper.abstract: The Experimental Physics and Industrial Control System (EPICS), is an open-source software framework for high-performance distributed control, and is at the heart of many of the world's large accelerators and telescopes. Recently, EPICS has undergone a major revision, with the aim of better computing supporting for the next generation of machines and analytical tools. Many new data types, such as matrices, tables, images, and statistical descriptions, plus users' own data types, now supplement the simple scalar and waveform types of the former EPICS. New computational architectures for scientific computing have been added for high-performance data processing services and pipelining. Python and Java bindings have enabled powerful new user interfaces. The result has been that controls are now being integrated with modelling and simulation, machine learning, enterprise databases, and experiment DAQs. We introduce this new EPICS (version 7) from the perspective of accelerator physics and review early adoption cases in accelerators around the world.

abstract_log.comments: Author is asked to add references to the Figures. Editor has updated the files with corrections for some known errors. So, please use the updated file. Other problems found are as follows: Figure 1 caption not fitted in the column width. A dot found before REFERENCES. Column widths were not consistent through the whole text: the reason will be that some sentences were written in a Table frame not in a normal column. Review records were not removed. Editor has added data in the References list. Editor has changed the Courier font of the list in Figure 1 to Courier New. Figure number 2 was duplicated. The second Figure must be Figure 3. There were no references to the Figures in text.
